image.altText: Paper lanterns floating on still water, seen from above.

props.synopsis: The American company behind a Canberra water lantern festival apologises for using the Commonwealth Coat of Arms without approval, and promises to issue refunds to hundreds of ticketholders if it can't secure a new venue.

title.children: Lantern festival promises refunds if  Canberra event can't go ahead

image.altText: blurry shot of a man and woman sitting on a park bench

props.synopsis: Chris has been using cannabis for the majority of his adult life, and says he used to get behind the wheel while under the influence, but it isn't something he does anymore.

title.children: Chris used to drive after smoking cannabis, but not anymore

image.altText: Jacob Vadakkedathu, Peter Dutton

props.synopsis: The Liberal Party's lead Senate candidate for the ACT has broken his silence over allegations of branch stacking, after a push to disendorse him failed at the weekend.

title.children: Liberal Senate candidate denies branch stacking claims

image.altText: Lachlan smiles after his run, holding up a medal.

props.synopsis: Despite Australia's rich history on the world indoor athletics stage, it still doesn't have an indoor facility.

title.children: Australia doesn't have an indoor athletics track, but this event is a short-term answer

image.altText: Unidentified guard opens secure door at Youth Justice centre

props.synopsis: A former youth offender sues the ACT government, alleging he was sexually assaulted by a guard at the former Quamby youth detention centre.

title.children: ACT government sued over alleged sexual assault by youth detention guard

image.altText: The exterior of a concrete building with the words "Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory" over the entrance.

props.synopsis: The court heard the victim had declined help or to pursue the matter with police at the time of the alleged assault, telling them he'd been "kicked by a horse".

title.children: Second Canberra man charged over 2020 death after family barbecue

image.altText: The wallet lies open on a bench, its contents displayed, including the Video Ezy card.

props.synopsis: When Tim Ceaser's wallet flew out his car window at 19 he thought it was gone forever, but three decades later a stranger reunited it with him through a local Facebook group after fishing it out of the Queabeyan River.

title.children: Video Ezy cards, 'decimated' money in 30yo wallet fished from river

image.altText: A photo of the club from out front, a large building with pillars, multistorey and with pillars.

props.synopsis: The Hellenic Club of Canberra is reprimanded and ordered to pay the ACT government $1.2 million after the death by suicide of a man who was in debt due to problem gambling using its poker machines.

title.children: Hellenic Club fined $1.2m over problem gambling of man who later died by suicide

image.altText: A man and woman in a carriage, dressed in formal wear, pulled by a black horse team

props.synopsis: World champion carriage driver Boyd Exell returns home to Australia this year to help students learn the ropes of a sport with royal roots.

title.children: A carriage-driving master brings his skills back home

image.altText: Chappell Roan performs during the 67th Annual Grammy Awards.

props.synopsis: In what could have been a difficult night for the Grammys as organisers staged music's biggest night in fire-ravaged Los Angeles, the awards show struck the right tone and put to bed controversies surrounding Beyoncé and The Weeknd.

title.children: Grammys settles Beyoncé and The Weeknd controversies

image.altText: A bag of fentanyl seized in a drug raid

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump has cited a need to stop illegal fentanyl flowing into the country as a reason for new tariffs against Mexico, Canada and China. Will it work?

title.children: Will Trump's tariffs on China, Canada and Mexico end the fentanyl epidemic?

image.altText: deepseek written on a phone

props.synopsis: What no-one talks about as the AI revolution unfolds in stock market hype and scientific gung-ho is what the developers are really trying to do. They're trying to replicate the human brain.

title.children: 'None of us will have a job': How DeepSeek is changing the world

image.altText: A woman wearing a red suit walks outside of court.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for Antoinette Lattouf have revealed private messages between senior ABC executives in Federal Court, arguing the journalist and presenter was fired due to her opinions about the conduct of the Israeli government in Gaza.

title.children: 'We owe her nothing': Buttrose's emails on Lattouf's departure revealed in court

image.altText: A crocodile at the waters edge jumping over a wave.

props.synopsis: Campers at a popular Queensland campsite are being warned to stay off the beach following a "credible" crocodile sighting.

title.children: Beachgoers warned of 'vagrant' crocodile near Queensland's Rainbow Beach

image.altText: A burnt-out building stands among burnt out trees on a country property.

props.synopsis: Grassfires sparked by lightning destroyed at least two homes in Victoria's north west overnight, with fears of more property losses to come as heatwave conditions continue across the state until Tuesday.

title.children: Lightning sparks new fires, houses destroyed as Victoria's heatwave continues

image.altText: Cash on a table

props.synopsis: The AEC has published political donations data for the past financial year, revealing Australia's major parties hauled in eight-figure sums.

title.children: Gambling, fossil fuel and big pharma open wallets for politicians

image.altText: A man sits at a desk during a parliamentary inquiry.

props.synopsis: A NSW parliamentary inquiry is told by a Blue Mountains campaigner that state government agencies worked together to deprive the public of information about PFAS contamination.

title.children: Government agencies accused of colluding to block ABC interviews on PFAS

image.altText: A head and shoulders shot of Perth Hebrew Congregation chief Rabbi Daniel Lieberman standing below a star of david on a wall.

props.synopsis: Police probe four instances of antisemitic graffiti across Perth in recent days as a local rabbi denounces a 'culture of vilification'.

title.children: Rabbi speaks out after 'alarming spike' in antisemitic graffiti in Perth

image.altText: A towering red rock over a desert landscape.

props.synopsis: Police say the 77-year-old Queensland woman was visiting Mount Augustus in WA's remote Gascoyne, where temperatures reached the high 40s over the weekend.

title.children: Tourist dies after leaving bogged car in heatwave conditions in WA

image.altText: Celeste Barber stands with arms folded leaning against a graffiti wall. She wears a red and black short sleeve dress

props.synopsis: Celeste Barber has found global fame for her Instagram parodies of A-listers. But behind the laughs is a story about the dark side of ADHD.

title.children: Celeste Barber has 9.6 million fans. She's struggled to be one of them

image.altText: A door smashed through, with shops in the background.

props.synopsis: Police say a person in a red Ford Falcon ute drove through the front glass doors of Gippsland Centre in Sale before exiting on the other side and fleeing the scene.

title.children: People duck for cover as man drives ute through Sale shopping centre

image.altText: A man speaking to a crowd with a backdrop of tropical plantlife.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of people have attended a state funeral for former judge and NT administrator Austin Asche, remembering him as an "excellent judge" who devoted his time to fostering the next generation of NT leaders.

title.children: Former judge and NT administrator Austin Asche farewelled at state funeral

image.altText: Icy poles and ice in a children's shell outdoor pool.

props.synopsis: With room temperatures reportedly reaching around 30 degrees inside the Launceston General Hospital, staff and patients have been given frozen treats to help them cope because of inadequate air-conditioning.

title.children: Ice treats given to patients, staff as hospital grapples with aircon fix

image.altText: view of homes in Liverpool leading into the horizon

props.synopsis: Will the cost-of-living crisis impact how you vote? These electorates are feeling the financial stress the most, but will it change the outcome on election day?

title.children: Postcodes of pain: These 'stressed' suburbs may swing the election

image.altText: A large pile of books and other debris outside a library building reaches almost to the second floor windows.

props.synopsis: When floods decimated the Lismore City Library in 2022, photos of the damage sparked a national outpouring of donations. At last, the space has reopened to the public.

title.children: 'Exhilarating' day as library reopens after floods destroyed 29,000 books

image.altText: Smoke haze

props.synopsis: Temperatures have climbed above 40C in parts of SA, with health authorities confirming several people went to hospital over the weekend with "heat-related illness".

title.children: Weather bureau warns of 'significant' tree branch risk amid SA heat

image.altText: Jennifer and Gretl Petelczyc who were shot dead in their own home by Mark James Bombara.

props.synopsis: Dennis Harvey says his family members would be alive today if police had done their job properly.

title.children: Furious brother of Floreat murder victim slams police commissioner, minister

image.altText: Peter Dutton, framed by a round window.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton is clearly connecting with disenfranchised young men better than progressives and Anthony Albanese are. The risk is how that translates across the electorate.

title.children: Is Peter Dutton Australia's man whisperer?

image.altText: A woman in a blue suit speaks at a press conference.

props.synopsis: NSW Transport Minister Jo Haylen is under more pressure after it emerged she used taxpayer-funded drivers on other occasions.

title.children: Jo Haylen used taxpayer-funded driver for additional personal trips

image.altText: Liam Ryan of the Eagles celebrates after kicking a goal, raising his arms over his head

props.synopsis: Premiership-winning West Coast Eagles player Liam Ryan has been cleared of any wrongdoing after footage emerged of him involved in a brawl at a festival last month.

title.children: AFL clears star player Liam Ryan of wrongdoing at festival

image.altText: A sign on top of a shelf of American whiskey says "Buy Canadian instead" with a red maple leaf

props.synopsis: US alcohol is just one of the products targeted for boycott and possible tariffs, Canadian authorities say.

title.children: Canada fights back against US tariffs as American products boycotted

image.altText: A composite image of Baldoni and Lively smiling at the It Ends With Us premiere

props.synopsis: Lawsuits have been filed and receipts have been released. Here's a basic breakdown of what's going on between actors Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni.

title.children: Unpacking the Justin Baldoni and Blake Lively lawsuits

image.altText: A small black whale with a white oval-shaped marking on its side pokes out of the water.

props.synopsis: A newborn killer whale calf spotted off the southern coast of WA could be one of the youngest ever seen in Australian waters.

title.children: Rare sighting of newborn orca off the WA coast

image.altText: A man with a grey beard and black cap and a blonde woman resting her hand on his shoulder smile in a radio studio.

props.synopsis: The radio host has revealed he will undergo brain surgery after being diagnosed with an aneurysm that requires "immediate attention".

title.children: Kyle Sandilands to undergo urgent brain surgery after aneurysm diagnosis

image.altText: Units. Housing

props.synopsis: The ongoing pressure of high interest rates and the cost of living has pushed down house prices in some capital cities, opening up the market for first home buyers.

title.children: 'Buyers' market' opens up in some areas as house prices flatten
